title: The Flawed Inflation Narrative; And “V” vs. “U”
text: While nuts and bolts economics indicates that deflation is still an issue going forward, inflation fears appear to be the driving force in this recent up move, with such fears ignited by the recent price spikes in commodities.

title: Stock Market Indexes At Crossroads: What's Next?
text: On Friday, three of the major stock market indices gapped lower ultimately closing negative for the week. The Russell 2000, although down on Friday, closed up on the week.

title: Window For IPOs 'Wide Open' In 2021, Says Nasdaq SVP
text: Jan.15 -- Jeff Thomas, Nasdaq SVP and head of West Coast listings, discusses their busiest week for capital raising in the past five years with 48 companies going public in the first half of January. He also talks about the big first-day pops technology companies have recently delivered on their IPO days.

title: Bill Ackman: The Bull Market Will Continue in 2021
text: With $13.1 billion in assets under management, Pershing Square Capital Management is far from the biggest hedge fund out there, but its moves and performance tend to garner considerable attention. That is due in part to the fact that its boss, Bill Ackman (Trades, Portfolio), has never shied away from the spotlight.

title: U.S. IPO Week Ahead: Foreign Issuers Dominate A 4-IPO Week
text: Four IPOs are scheduled to raise $1.8 billion in the shortened holiday week, featuring a diverse group of foreign issuers. China's leading e-cigarette brand RLX Technology plans to raise $1.0 billion at a $14.0 billion market cap.

title: Bad News Is Good News
text: Even though news around the vaccine campaign may affect the dynamics of asset prices slightly, it will not be the most important factor in 2021. Any bad news about the pandemic (delays in vaccine, tougher restrictions) is a good news for markets (more liquidity).

title: Goldman Sachs nudges U.S. growth forecast higher on Biden stimulus plan
text: Analysts at Goldman Sachs Group raised their U.S. growth forecast for the second time this month on expectations that President-elect Joe Biden's fiscal stimulus plan will hasten the economy's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: No Taper, No Tantrum: Powell Alleviates Worries Of Scale-Back In Quantitative Easing
text: Fed chairman stresses continuance of asset-purchasing program. Details of Biden's proposed $1.9 trillion stimulus package.

title: The Biden Fiscal Plan For The Economy
text: The change in administrations is coming soon and the fiscal approach to the running of the economy is about to change, dramatically. The sense of the program president-elect Biden is proposing is largely a replay of earlier policy efforts of the Obama administration and a continuation of the policy of "credit inflation."

title: SPY: Are Equities Irrationally High? Low Opportunity Costs Suggest The Answer Is No
text: SPY is trading at all-time highs. Minor volatility in the short-term is dwarfed by recent performance. While bigger corrections cannot be ruled out, low opportunity costs indicate that SPY (a low-cost ETF) still deserves allocation.

title: Week Ahead - Earnings Season In Focus
text: Earnings season is under way and will become an increasing focus in the coming weeks. New variants of Covid-19 are causing major surges across many countries which is forcing more severe and extended restrictions.

title: Consumers, Producers, And The Unsettled End Of 2020
text: The months of November and December aren't always easily comparable year to year when it comes to American shopping habits. The Census Bureau tells us that, unadjusted, November seemed low and December appeared better (revised 2.00% year-over-year and 4.85%, respectively).

title: S&P 500 price falls as Goldman Sachs chief economist issues a warning
text: S&P 500 price closed the week nearly 1.5% lower to record the biggest weekly pullback since October. On the other hand, Goldman Sachs warns that stocks and bond markets could see a short-term pullback, after hitting record highs a week earlier.

title: Market Snapshot: Biden's ‘rescue America' plan is big. How its trillions could help both Wall Street and Main Street
text: President-elect Joe Biden's proposal to spent another $1.9 trillion to help fight the pandemic and its shocks is putting Wall Street on inflation-watch. But investors say the U.S. economy and financial markets would be worse off without it.

title: The Destructive Force And Failure Of QE
text: This article concludes that quantitative easing as a means of stimulating economies and financing government deficits will fail. The underlying assumption is that the transmission of additional money to non-banks in order to inflate financial assets, and to banks to cover government finances, will become too great in 2021 for it to succeed without undermining fiat currencies and financial markets.

title: Investing In The Next Decade: The Future Is Green
text: Green tech is in 1994...not 1999. A new commodities supercycle to come.

title: Adrenaline-fueled rush for small caps, vaccine plays and story stocks dents passive-indexing trend
text: The most dramatic market action is happening beyond the reach of the S&P 500 in small caps, new shares like Snowflake and penny stocks.

title: 3 Stock Market Predictions for Another ‘Year Like No Other'
text: By Robert Ross Investors might have thought they'd seen it all in 2020. But the stock market action was merely a preview of what's to come in 2021.

title: Energy stocks could pull a Tesla and go parabolic in 2021, Fundstrat's Tom Lee says
text: Energy stocks could see a reversal in fortunes this year after a dismal showing in 2020 and stage a parabolic surge like Tesla, Fundstrat's Tom Lee said in a note on Thursday. The energy sector fell 37% in 2020 and briefly saw oil prices dip into negative territory as the COVID-19 pandemic and ensuing travel restrictions sparked a collapse in demand. Over the same time period, Tesla soared 743% as the company managed to barely miss its 500,000 full-year delivery goal by only a few hundred cars.

title: Manufacturing Output Rose In December, But Remains Below Pre-Pandemic Levels
text: Industrial production rose 1.6 percent in December. Over the past year, industrial production is down 3.6 percent and 3.3 percent below the pre-pandemic level in February.

title: Retail Sales Decline For A Third Consecutive Month
text: Retail sales and food-services spending posted a third consecutive decline in December. Core retail sales, which exclude motor vehicles and gasoline retailers, posted a sharp 2.1 percent drop for the month.

title: Five things you need to know about on the markets this week – Biden, big banks and central banks, bond yields, and Bitcoin
text: Stock markets finished the second week of January having reached all-time highs, overlooking fairly gruesome US labor market data, the ongoing explosion in cases of COVID-19 and unprecedented political turmoil in the final days of Donald Trump's presidency, as he faces impeachment – again.  Reflation has been the name of the game across the markets and anything even remotely economically sensitive has surged, including small-cap stocks, oil and gas and, of course, cryptocurrencies, particularly following Joe Biden's plans for a $1.9 trillion stimulus package.

title: Rallying Behind The Latest Moves In Emerging Markets
text: Emerging market equities cooked up a massive rally at the end of 2020, gaining 55% over the last nine months of the year and beating the S&P 500 Index by nearly 8%. Within many WisdomTree ETF Model Portfolios, the anchor position that captures this positive sentiment about EM is a core allocation to the WisdomTree Emerging Market ex-State-Owned Enterprises Fund.

title: Come Together Now
text: Financial markets continue to be liquidity-driven as both our government and Fed are all in. The market remains undervalued with a 12-24-month outlook supported by a strong economy, record earnings, excess liquidity and relatively low interest rates.

title: The Week On Wall Street; Everyone Is Bullish
text: The economic data continues to confirm a "V"-shaped recovery. Stimulus, stimulus and more stimulus; be on the lookout for what comes next.

title: Weekly High Frequency Indicators: Jobless Claims Worsen, But Vaccination Rate Improves
text: High frequency indicators can give us a nearly up-to-the-moment view of the economy. The metrics are divided into long leading, short leading, and coincident indicators.
